Would you have any idea what compilation unit you were editing when you got the
IllegalArgumentException? We have another open PR about the same issue, but no
steps to reproduce.

This error "Invalid string literal : >>",<" (I added some logging) means that a
string literal was created with >", escaped string. This is not a valid escaped
string. We have to find out how we got there.
I will investigate.

I am afraid not..it was a a minute before I had realised that eclipse had 
deadlocked and by the time I had looked at the console copied and pasted 
everything I had forgotten what I was doing!

Too bad. I cannot find out how we end up with an invalid escaped value for a
string literal. I tried to create a compilation unit that contained that invalid
string, but I didn't get the IllegalArgumentException.
If you get it again, please attach the given compilation unit.

Do you remember having a binary expression as the argument of a method
invocation containing string literals? This is what seems to be wrong.
Thanks for your help.
nope... not in the code I am writing...perhaps in the libraries I am using!

Did you yse the "Occurences in file" action? If yes, I need to see the
compilation unit in which you did this.
I never use that. I only use "references in Workspace".

the error I reported was in the console window. However in the log there is

Created an attachment (id=6866)
the file in which the error occured

There is a case where the source positions of the string literal are boggus. I
will track it down. Thanks a lot again for your help. It is really appreciated.

Did you touch the line containing:

append("Attempting to reload Subscriber Template with name: " + identifier);

I tried to reproduce with the file you attached, but it could be converted
without a problem. So something is wrong with the position of the string while
editing it.

I don't know why, but it seems that an offset of 1 is introduced wrongly in the
string literal positions. In your last example, the literal should be:
"Attempting to reload Subscriber Template with name: "
but it is:
Attempting to reload Subscriber Template with name: " 
With a trailing space.
The former is a valid string literal, not the latter. I am investigating how the
string literal can end up with invalid positions while the compilation unit is
converted.
Don't hesitate to attach other code snippets if you get it again.

Close as duplicate of bug 46012

*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 46012 ***

traces.message: Invalid string literal : >Attempting to  reload Subscriber Template with name: " <
